title: Understanding Absolute Cell References
text: Absolute cell references in Excel are denoted by a dollar sign ($) before the column letter and row number. For example, $A$1 is an absolute reference.

title: Why Use Absolute References?
text: When using functions like VLOOKUP or HLOOKUP, absolute references ensure that the table array remains constant even if the formula is copied to another cell.

hintAnswer: The table array reference will change, potentially leading to incorrect results.
title: Effect of Relative References
text: What happens if you use relative references in a VLOOKUP function and then copy the formula to another cell?
choices: The table array reference will change, potentially leading to incorrect results.
The table array reference will remain the same.
The formula will not work at all.

hintAnswer: so that Excel will not adjust the table array location when it creates the calculated column
title: Correct Use of Absolute References
text: What is the main reason for using absolute cell references in VLOOKUP and HLOOKUP functions?
choices: so that Excel will not adjust the table array location when it creates the calculated column
there is no reason to use absolute cell references
lookup functions only accept absolute cell references
